passages.text: Aug 29: SFR/ILD results OD/Glafaser, UK Altnet challenges...
SFR- Weak Q2 financials and KPIs reinforce need for consolidation (note out yesterday)
Iliad - Q2 French growth slows. Record margins (op leverage + BTS). Italy M&A commentary (note out yesterday)

Altice International - Confirmed bid for Israel's Hot Telecom unit Vodafone - Freezes wholesale agreement with Deutsche Glasfaser UK Altnets - UK banks set to take losses on loans to altnets UK Altnets - CommunityFibre launches data roaming eSIM mobile plan BT - UK government boosts value of Openreach's Project Gigabit framework by £400m
Telia - Publishes offer document to the shareholders of Bredband2 US Telcos - Starlink and Kuiper possible beneficiaries of Echostar's remaining spectrum
Sunrise - Launches new Home Security packages for households Sinch - Introduces new RCS campaign capabilities on its Sinch Engage platform
Sunrise US roadshow - New York (8 Sept) and Boston (9 Sept) UK Leaders Conference (Vodafone and BT to attend) - London (18- 19 Nov) Please reach out for more details.
Recent research (here) Selected dates (here)

J.P. Morgan does and seeks to do business with companies covered in its research reports. As a result, investors should be aware that the firm may have a conflict of interest that could affect the objectivity of this report. Investors should consider this report as only a single factor in making their investment decision.
H2 – Germany’s final decision on Vodafone/Vantage anti- competitive hindrance to 1&1 2025 – Norwegian 1500MHz and 26GHz spectrum auction (TBC, consultation ongoing)
Sources: Company reports, Bloomberg Finance L.P., Reuters See full calendar below

SFR released its Q2 results yesterday. Both financials and KPIs are weaker than expectations. We believe this will serve to further reinforce SFR’s need for market consolidation, supporting press reports that indicate the company is hoping to conclude a deal by year- end: (1) Revenues ex La Poste and Media €2,287m -9.0% y/y (Q1 -6.2%). Also excluding construction, revenues are -7.4% (Q1 -5.8%, Q4’24 -4.1%). The sequential worsening reflects a marked deterioration in residential service revenues -9.1% y/y (Q1 -6.7%, Q4’24 -1.8%) which outpaced the decline in SFR’s average customer base. Management attribute this to front book price pressures and reduced “other” fixed services, (2) EBITDA ex La Poste, Media and Datacentre €801m -10.8% y/y is similar to Q1 -11.8% (FY24 -9.4%), (3) Capex €378m -24% y/y. Hence, OpFCF €271m was “only” -4.3% y/y and management indicated they expect FY25 OpFCF to grow y/y with EBITDA declines more than offset by falling capex, (4) Net debt €21.4bn or 6.6x EBITDA. Pro- forma for the refinancing, net debt €15.8bn or 5.3x L2QA, (5) Against the backdrop of such weak trends, we reiterate our view that SFR standalone is only worth €16bn (see here), implying very limited equity value, and suggesting the only route to value creation is through in- market consolidation. Whilst Patrick Drahi is no doubt a shrewd deal- maker, against the backdrop of weak results, regulatory considerations, execution risks, and the size of the overall transaction, we have argued a price tag of >€20bn (6.3x EV/EBITDA) is more credible (though clearly weak trends can erode this level). We have published extensively on consolidation prospects (see here, here, here, here, here, here, and here).

Iliad reported its Q2’25 results yesterday. Key highlights included: (1) Q4 revenues: Growth rates across Poland and Italy are broadly unchanged. However, France has suffered another sequential slowdown with Q2 organic revenue growth +2.1% (Q1 +3.3%, Q4’24 +5.4%, Q3’24 +8.4%). In the mix, French service revenue growth is +0.9% y/y (Q1 +3.8%, Q4’24 +4.9%, Q3’24 +7.5%). The ~3pp q/q slowdown this quarter is greater than the 1.2pp slowdown at Orange and the 1.9pp at Bouygues, (2) No longer reporting French KPIs: Italian and Polish net adds have sequentially ticked up. However, in France management now only reported their subscriber base rounded to the nearest 0.1m, making it impossible to calculate net add trends, (3) impressive margin trends: Iliad has delivered record margins across all regions this quarter: France 44.7% (+3.6pp y/y), Italy 33.3% (+6.2% y/y) and Poland 46.1% (+4.3pp y/y). Looking at the company’s cost disclosure (P6 of the accounts), around half of the EBITDA growth seems attributable to “other income and expenses from operations” (split 50% tower BTS and other), whilst the other half seems to reflect operating leverage / cost control, (4) Consolidation: Iliad’s CEO at a press conference is quoted as saying “we didn’t have any discussions with Telecom Italia since the beginning of April, and these will come back… these perspectives are now behind us”. This has seen Telecom Italia’s shares -8% today. Investors will look to Iliad’s earnings call to provide more colour on the French Telco competitive environment, as well as the evolving dialogue around a potential SFR “break- up”, including whether this week’s political developments might in any way complicate an M&A process.
Altice International said it has received an offer for its Israeli business, Hot Telecommunication Systems. One of Hot’s competitors in Israel made the bid and the

company will consider it, an Altice spokesman said, declining to give further details. Hot's EBITDA declined \(7.5\%\) on a constant currency basis in Q2 to €78m on revenue of about €251m, Altice International said in its financial results Thursday. Altice International also said Hot agreed to sell its \(23\%\) stakes its IBC fibre- optic business to a consortium of Israeli financial institutions in June. Horndi bought the holding for €45.4m in 2021. Altice International has also explored plans sell businesses in the Dominican Republic and Portugal. In addition to Hot, Drahi also launched Tel Aviv- based news channel i24News in 2013. (Source: Bloomberg)

Vodafone Germany informed its dealers of a "marketing freeze" for services on the Deutsche Glasfaser network in the middle of August, according to a report by business magazine WirtschaftsWoche (WiWo). Vodafone had announced that it was starting to offer its products on Deutsche Glasfaser's fibre networks in October 2024. Deutsche Glasfaser says its agreement with Vodafone remains in effect but "negotiations regarding wholesale terms are currently under way". The report says that Vodafone calls Deutsche Glasfaser's prices above the market average and that under current conditions "it is not possible to offer attractive deals". It added that more could be behind the dispute, saying that two anonymous sources within sales told it that a conspicuously high number of orders with Deutsche Glasfaser generated by Vodafone had been cancelled, leaving Vodafone dealers without commission. Deutsche Glasfaser then concluded the deals directly, the sources said. WiWo commented that both companies deny this. One sales insider told WiWo there were problems even in the early days of the marketing agreement, as Deutsche Glasfaser connections could not be recorded in the system easily. This led Vodafone to sign more Deutsche Telekom contracts, the source said. WiWo pointed out that the timing of the Vodafone's supposed sales freeze roughly coincides with 1&1 announcing that it would market Deutsche Glasfaser connections at the beginning of August. In November 2022, Deutsche Glasfaser announced that it had signed a wholesale agreement with Vodafone that would run for at least 10 years. (Source: Telecompaper)

Fibre eSIM is essentially a prepaid 4G and 5G capable data plan with support for tethering and “no hidden fees, charges, or contracts”, which can also be topped up at any time, even when you’re offline. The flexible data roaming plans, which can be used alongside your existing physical SIM and number, allows users to choose the amount of data they need and the number of days they’ll need it for before travel. The announcement claims customers can “save up to 96% with our prepaid data plans in over 160 countries”. The 96% compares Community Fibre eSIM for 1GB for 7 days in the US (£2.29) vs Vodafone’s daily roaming rates. The new service is being supporting by a new Community Fibre eSIM App and ISPreview notes that it doesn’t seem possible to bring up any pricing via the eSIM page on their website, which suggests that this may only be possible if you install their App first. (Source: ISPreview)

The government has modified the Single Supplier Framework agreement that it awarded to Openreach (BT) last year under the Project Gigabit broadband roll- out scheme (here). The deal was originally valued at “up to” £800m and designed to help upgrade 312k premises in some of the hardest to reach UK areas to FTTP, but this has just been boosted in value to £1.2bn. The framework agreement was later followed by the gradual awarding of seven related Cross- Regional (Type C) contracts to Openreach covering poorly served areas. The seven call- off contracts that have so far been awarded under the framework agreement reflect a total of over £730m in committed public investment and nearly 300k premises. In addition, any future fibre build delivered through this framework won’t have to go through another competitive process each time. The government states that the reason for this £400m increase stems from: 1) The need for additional works, services or supplies by Openreach and, 2) Additional scope has been added to the contract in accordance with the UK subsidy control regime. This suggests that either the aforementioned contracts are going to be extended to cover additional premises or the roll- out is costing more than expected (possibly also a combination of the two), says ISPreview. However, it is also possible the framework may have needed some adjustment for other reasons, such as to compensate for the fact that a number of smaller altnets have recently either withdrawn or scaled- back their own Project Gigabit deployments. (Source: ISPreview)

On July 18, 2025, Telia announced a recommended public offer to the shareholders of Bredband2 to tender all shares in Bredband2 to Telia. This morning, Telia published the offer document. The acceptance period of the offer commences on September 1, 2025, and ends on October 17, 2025. Settlement is expected to commence on or around October 24, 2025. The announcement in July reflected a cash offer of SEK 3.25 per share to the shareholders of Bredband2, valuing the company at EV SEK3,111m. Bredband2 is the third- largest provider of fibre internet to Swedish consumers, operating in open networks. The offer is unanimously recommended by Bredband2's Board of Directors. The five- largest shareholders, holding about 50.2% of the shares, have committed to accept. The offer price represents a 37% premium over the last closing price. Telia said it aims to acquire more than 90% of Bredband2's shares, with plans to maintain the Bredband2 brand post- acquisition. (Source: Telia)

Semafor reported on Tuesday that T- Mobile and Musk’s SpaceX had both bid for part or all of EchoStar’s spectrum, following AT&T’s announcement to acquire 50MHz of Echostar’s spectrum. Yesterday, Semafor reported that T- Mobile’s owners, Deutsche Telekom, had tapped the brakes, and it is unclear whether SpaceX, which envisions a satellite- to- ground cellphone network through Starlink, is still interested in the remaining spectrum that AT&T

didn't acquire. Peter Adderton, who co- founded Boost Mobile, said in an interview with Semafor, that he urged the FCC to consider competition when weighing approvals for AT&T's purchase. "Everything that they do is to ensure that nobody else has a leg up on them," Adderton told Semafor of the big carriers. Adderton sees Verizon as another possible beneficiary, while Amazon, with its own satellite network, Kuiper, could step into the fray. (Source: Semafor)

Swiss operator Sunrise announced the launch of a new Home Security service for its own service and customers of other providers. The service offers two packages for different home security needs - Home Security Basic and Home Security Complete. These combine security devices, a control app, on- site security services and insurance coverage and support from partner Zurich Insurance. For CHF 29.90 per month, Home Security Basic gives users access to features including a control app, live images and notifications, real- time alarm centre for up to six users, geofencing, attendance simulation and pet detection. For CHF 39.90 per month, Home Security Complete also offers at- home advice and installation, on- site intervention with Swiss Alarm Guard, and Sunrise Home Assistance through Zurich Insurance. Both subscriptions are offered with a minimum 12- month contract and require customers to buy the Home Security Set for CHF 289.90. Customers will also require a fixed- line broadband connection from any provider. An introductory promotion offers customers a CHF 10 per month discount on both plans, plus a CHF 60 discount on the security device set. (Source: Telecompaper)

Sinch has announced the addition of RCS campaign capabilities to its AI- powered Sinch Engage platform. Sinch Engage now features RCS (Rich Communication Services), allowing for branded, interactive mobile experiences that go far beyond standard SMS. The announcement will be featured at HubSpot INBOUND's Partner Day on September 2, in San Francisco, where Sinch will spotlight the platform's blend of real- time AI and rich messaging to transform the customer journey. "The future of customer engagement is not just about sending messages; it's about starting intelligent, timely, and deeply personal conversations," said Julia Fraser, Executive Vice President of the Americas at Sinch. "We're equipping HubSpot partners to lead this industry shift. By integrating powerful AI with the rich, interactive capabilities of RCS and WhatsApp, Sinch Engage turns every customer touchpoint into a genuine opportunity for connection and growth." By combining AI and rich messaging, with deep HubSpot integration, Sinch Engage empowers growth- focused businesses to connect with customers at scale through trusted, personalised communications, the company said. (Source: Sinch)

Analyst Certification: The Research Analyst(s) denoted by an "AC" on the cover of this report certifies (or, where multiple Research Analysts are primarily responsible for this report, the Research Analyst denoted by an "AC" on the cover or within the document individually certifies, with respect to each security or issuer that the Research Analyst covers in this research) that: (1) all of the views expressed in this report accurately reflect the Research Analyst's personal views about any and all of the subject securities or issuers; and (2) no part of any of the Research Analyst's compensation was, is, or will be directly or indirectly related to the specific recommendations or views expressed by the Research Analyst(s) in this report. For all Korea-based Research Analysts listed on the front cover, if applicable, they also certify, as per KOFIA requirements, that the Research Analyst's analysis was made in good faith and that the views reflect the Research Analyst's own opinion, without undue influence or intervention.

All authors named within this report are Research Analysts who produce independent research unless otherwise specified. In Europe, Sector Specialists (Sales and Trading) may be shown on this report as contacts but are not authors of the report or part of the Research Department.

J.P. Morgan uses the following rating system: Overweight (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will outperform the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe); Neutral (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will perform in line with the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe); and Underweight (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will underperform the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe. NR is Not Rated. In this case, J.P. Morgan has removed the rating and, if applicable, the price target, for this stock because of either a lack of a sufficient fundamental basis or for legal, regulatory or policy reasons. The previous rating and, if applicable, the price target, no longer should be relied upon. An NR designation is not a recommendation or a rating. In Americas equity research, some stocks under coverage have a rating but no price target; in these cases, we expect the stock will outperform/perform in line/underperform the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe over the next six to 12 months. In our Asia (ex- Australia and ex- India) and U.K. small- and mid- cap Equity Research, each stock's expected total return is compared to the expected total return of a benchmark country market index, not to those Research Analysts' coverage universe. If it does not appear in the Important Disclosures section of this report, the certifying Research Analyst's coverage universe can be found on J.P. Morgan's Research website, https://www.jpmorganmarkets.com.
